Hi,

As Roger can't answer right now, I'll answer on his behalf and he corr=
ect me if I get anything wrong.

We had this problem when using 3.1.1-SNAPS=
HOT, so we may evaluate the fixes in 3.1.2-SNAPSHOT. However, at domain-cra=
wl scale this kind of thing can generate a lot of negative feeling, so we'l=
l probably stick with out alternative, which is as follows:

Instead of usi=
ng the JavaScript extractor, we sent a subset of pages (specifically, the s=
eeds) to a headless browser service based on PhantomJS. That renders each s=
eed and enumerates all the resource dependencies (including JavaScript ones=
). The URLs discovered in this way are then passed back to H3 and downloade=
d. We believe this is a preferable approach, but it is difficult to find de=
cent quality-based metrics to allow these alternatives to be compared meani=
ngfully. We're doing some work on developing quality metrics, but it's stil=
l early days.

Andy Jackson
